item.title: WiMAX 2 Will Challenge Fiber For Speed
item.description: The idea that copper and wireless technologies are outdated in terms of bandwidth is circulating. While copper has found new life as a last-mile solution for Metro Ethernet services, and wireless stands out for its unmatched mobility, a new wireless technology is emerging that might surpass even fiber optic speeds. It’s surprising to think that wireless could outpace fiber in terms of bandwidth. While not all fiber optic services offer top speeds of 10 GigE, with many customers receiving 50 to 100 Mbps, especially in the case of Fiber To The Home (FTTH), the prospect of achieving 100 to 300 Mbps wirelessly anywhere in a city is enticing.

item.title: Ciena Takes New Bandwidth Technologies On The Road
item.description: Today, June 29th, those in Waltham, MA can experience cutting-edge carrier bandwidth technology firsthand. Visit the Ciena Innovation Lab to see live demonstrations of their latest optical, Ethernet, and software solutions. The lab will move to its next location in White Marsh, MD on July 15th. What exactly is the Ciena Innovation Lab? It’s a mobile showcase housed in a semi-trailer, packed with the most recent advancements in telecom and networking.

item.title: Backhaul Upgrades For Wireless Broadband
item.description: A curious thing occurred on the path to widespread mobile broadband: we hit a bandwidth bottleneck. While the focus was on wireless channels as the potential constraint, it’s the insufficient backhaul capacity that’s now jeopardizing the expansion of wireless services. Fortunately, this issue is being acknowledged and addressed. But what exactly is backhaul, and how does it impede mobile services? Backhaul, in its current usage, refers to the connection linking a wireless tower site back to the provider’s central office or mobile switching center.
